content.description: Sit start a bit left of the tree on a good flake/jug. Head straight up with a long move to a an obvious vertical pocket, and continue up on pockets and side pulls, trending a bit right when nearing the top. Finish with a slightly dicey top out.
content.protection: 2 or 3 pads. The route migrates a bit. A spotter would be nice as the top out is a little dicey.
content.location: This is on the first boulder above the parking, the same as Stir the Pie. From the trail head, take one of two trails up the hill to the right to the first boulder. Wretch is in the middle of the long face, vertical face that faces the trail head, around the corner to the right of Stir the Pie. It starts just left of the tree.

content.description: This problem starts on an obvious slopey mouth. Go left hand to a small pocket crimp then get a right heel on the start. Do a long move to a slopey crimp and bump again right hand to a bigger crimp. Top out straight up through some good holds. This problem feels harder if you cant use the pocket crimp.
content.location: Its the last problem on the Lactation Station wall.

content.description: Start at the two big eye-level pockets and proceed straight up to sloper edge. Mantle finish is tricky but has good holds.
content.location: Immediately to the right of Vertical Ice

content.description: If your looking at Baldwin bash and lactation station look right and this is the boulder with vertical ice. This problem is on the steep side of the boulder. It starts low (not quite a sit start) and climbs straight up the face via gastons and pockets. I felt like the topout was easy but I saw a few people fall off the top.
content.location: On the boulder to the right of lactation station

content.description: Stand start on holds right next to the big sloping ledge and head up and slightly right, possibly using a gaston
content.location: Cow patty boulder

content.description: Another great moderate on the Cow Patty Boulder. Stand start on pockets about 8 feet left of Scooby Snacks (6 feet right of Cook the Patty). Climb up pockets to a crimp at the lip, and top out with a somewhat committing mantle.
content.location: This is on the Cow Patty Boulder, directly above the parking. It is the line of pockets about 8 feet left of Scooby Snacks.

content.description: This problem is on the first boulder you see while hiking up the hill. It starts sitting and climbs directly out the overhang to an easy topout. Probably the easiest v9 ever, but it's joes, just roll with it.
content.location: Just downhill from Baldwin bash and lactation station.

content.description:
An excellent problem on great rock. A bit out of the way and hard to find, but worth the effort.

Stand start directly below the left end of a slanting, 3 foot long rail, on a side pull crimp. Move up to the bottom of the rail, then continue up and left through good pockets to the lip. Easy top out.
content.protection: A pad. It's a bit tall, but has a good landing.
content.location: This problem as well as Smoke One Later is on the Joint Ravine Boulder. From the Dairy Canyon car park, head up the ravine. After passing the turn off to Winder Dairy (Milkman, Milkstache, 2%), continue up the ravine on a faint trail that is on the right side of the ravine bottom, for about 10-15 minutes. The boulder is on the right, in the trees about 50 feet or so above the ravine bottom, and is easy to miss. It is directly above a big orange boulder in the ravine bottom. The problems are on the side that faces down canyon.

content.description:
As with Smoke One Now, I thought this really good, and worth the effort to get too. Perhaps a bit low in the grade.

Start standing on a side pull crimp, below the left end of an obvious 3 foot long slanting rail in the middle of the face. Make a move to the bottom of the rail (as in Smoke One Now). Move to the right end of the rail, then up to a thin flake/crimp (don't pull too hard on it!). Reach up to a good pinch below the lip, then then to the sloping top for a committing mantle.
content.location: Follow the directions in the description of Smoke One Now, to get to Joint Ravine Boulder. It is on the side of the boulder facing down canyon.

content.description: Start low on the big hueco and make moves up the face through pockets to a big throw to a sloper and a "techy" mantle.
content.location: About ten feet around the corner to the right of Stir the Pie

content.description:
This route is located 10 feet right of lactation station. It starts right hand in a mail slot and left hand on sloper sidepull. It climbs slopers, pockets, and a crimp to a engaging topout.

On a historical note I once saw someone slide down the tree stripper style while bailing on the topout.
content.location: 10 feet right of lactation station

content.description: Start standing on small shelf, negotiating monos, pockets, and crimps
content.protection: several pads and a spotter. Landing is sloped
content.location: This problem is on the opposite side of Vertical Ice

content.description:
AKA:

Milkmaid

- Start standing on huge jugs. Climb straight up the face through some really good pockets to gain some slopey dishes at the top.

Pretty straight forward top out.

Cool features and pretty good quality rock (a little sandy like most of Dairy Canyon) make this a worthwhile climb.
content.protection: A few pads are ideal. Perhaps a spotter to keep you from rolling down the hill if you fall near the top.
content.location: Located on the Milkman boulder. It starts just right of '2 Percent'.

content.description: A very good sit start to a really amazing problem. Sit start at low pockets at the arete. The tree is surprisingly not as dabby as it may seem. The boulder is always cold and makes for a good late season project when the lower Joe’s valley is too warm.
content.protection: Multiple pads (~5). Spotter is important. Landing is not optimal.
content.location: Dairy canyon. See description for milk man.

content.description: This problem is amazing!!! And always sooo cold. To get to this boulder, park in the same place as you would for lactation station, but instead of hiking up the hill, hike up the gully for 5 minutes, this boulder is on your left. The original Milkman is a stand start on two awesome slopers. There has been a sit start added (v10 or 11)
content.protection: A bunch of pads, strange landing.
content.location: 5 minutes up the gully

content.description: This route starts 10 feet right of the Baldwin Bash. It starts crossed on 2 pockets and heads straight out the bulge via perfect slopers.
content.location: 10 feet right of Baldwin Bash

content.description: This is the link-up of Lactation Station into Rabbit Fur. Saw it in the old Caldero guidebook and was quite surprised by how well this problem flows. So here ya go. Start on the pockets of Lactation Station and work through slopers linking into the crux moves of Rabbit Fur. Adds a nice punch to an already quality line.
content.location: Start on Lactation Station and work right in Rabbit Fur.

content.description: Invert offwidth revert. Sit start at the back of the overhang, feet first in the crack. Most of the difficulty revolves around getting the right way up when the crack widens. Easier for those with large knees (knee pads unacceptable). Star rating dependent on appreciation of struggle. The name comes from a Stewart Lee sketch (British stand up comedian), and the problems resemblance to... A huge anus.
content.location: The obvious wide crack in the middle of the crag, slightly left of lactation station

content.description: Sit Start on a jug undercling. Go right on small gaston edges then lock off and cross left to a small edge above your right hand. Make big move to good holds at the lip. Easy top out
content.protection: The floor slants down so you need atleast 2 pads and a spotter.
content.location: On the Cow patty boulder. Its the right most problem on the face

content.description:
Sit start at the bottom of the obvious Flake undercling that diagonals upwards from the right to the left, just right of the tree. Pull on and undercling the flake up and left to it's end, then head straight up on good holds to the top, the last hold or two not being obvious from below. The first couple of moves are the crux.

There is a V2 stand start, that begins at the end of the flake and finishes the same.
content.location: This is on the first boulder above the parking, the same as Stir the Pie. From the trail head, take one of two trails up the hill to the right to the first boulder. Cowboy is to the right of the middle of the long vertical face that faces the trail head, around the corner to the right of Stir the Pie. It starts just right of the tree.

content.description: Sit start on the blunt arete, about 15-20 feet left of Cow Bell. Climb up on widely space flakes, to lower angle terrain. The first few moves are the hardest. Very high quality, and one of the few good warm ups in Dairy Canyon.
content.location: On the same cliff band as Baldwin Bash and Lactation Station. On the left most block of the cliff band. From the car park, hike up the trail on the hill side to the right, and continue about a hundred yards past the first boulder (Stir the Pie).

content.description: Sit start on pockets under the bulge. A hard drive by move to a decent pocket over the lip with the right hand is the crux. After attaining the jug side pull, there is a very cool, big move to top out. Excellent problem!
content.protection: A pad or two. Landing is good.
content.location: The route starts about 25 feet to the left of Baldwin Bash on pockets under the obvious bulge. To get there from the parking, head up the hillside on the obvious trail to the right. Pass the first boulder (Stir the Pie), and continue on for about a hundred yards to the low cliff band with Baldwin Bash and Lactation Station.

content.description: Sit start at the base of the arete, about 5 feet to the right of Stir the Pie, with hands on good incuts on either side of the arete. Climb up the arete on an assortment of crimps, side pulls  and pockets until reaching a series of good crimps that trend left just below the lip. Follow these (bumping the right hand) until you can reach the obvious sloping hueco on Stir the Pie. Finish up on that route.
content.protection: Two or three pads. There are a couple of small boulders below the start.
content.location: The route is on the first boulder on the hillside to the right, above the parking. Follow one of two short trails to get there. Facing the boulder from the parking area, the route is on the left, overhanging side, and starts about 5 feet to the right of Stir the Pie.

content.description: AKA: DK Dyno- Stand start about 10 feet to the right of Rabbit Fur, with your hands in a threader pocket. Pull the feet on and make a huge move with the left hand to a jug side pull. Climb past another couple of jugs to an interesting top out. A very fun problem! Rated V7 in the Caldiero guide, but probably easier.
content.protection: A couple of pads. The landing is good.
content.location: The same cliff band as Baldwin Bash and Lactation Station. From the car park, walk up the trail on the hill side to the right, and continue about a hundred yards past the first boulder (Stir the Pie).

content.description:
Someone

has to appreciate wide boulder cracks - and that someone can be you!

Wriggle half inside the offwidth crack and half on faceholds to the top.  Try to dodge the nub that pokes into your crotch as you hug the arete near the top - it poked a hole through my pants in a bad spot!  All in all this problem is a pretty fun change of style.

Start standing and part-wriggled into the crack.

P.S. Considering the V6ish wide crack to the right has been climbed before, it's probable this has too - if so just hmu and I'll change the FA.
content.location: On the Lactation Station boulder.  It's the wide-time crack on the far left between DK's Bulge and Cowbell.

content.description: Start on left-hand slot and right hand pocket, negotiate the bulge up to a slopey top-out
content.protection: Crash-pads and a spotter... good landing
content.location: On the left side of the cliff band as approached from below.  There is a rock and branch platform built up where pads can be placed and the spotter can brace against the tree to prevent you from tumbling down the hill Chris Farley style... most landings are mild, however.

content.description:
Start standing with your right hand in a good hidden pocket at 6 feet and your left hand wherever. (You can start lower but it adds no difficulty.)

Climb the face using assorted pockets and slopers to a slopey and somewhat tricky top out.

This climb would be better if it didn't get so close to the problem to the right- 'Milkstache'.
content.protection: A few pads are great. Perhaps a spotter to make sure you don't go rolling down the hill if you fall from the top.
content.location: Located on the Milkman boulder. It is on the mostly vertical face to the left of Milkman and is the problem just right of a tree.
